concept.title: Index page references
concept.shortdesc: Typically, an indexterm element instructs a processor to generate an index entry with a page reference.

conbody.p: The nesting of indexterm elements and the presence of redirection elements has an effect on page references in the generated index:

ul.li: An indexterm element that does not contain child indexterm elements (or an index-see element) contributes a page number to the generated index.

An indexterm element that contains child indexterm elements contributes to the hierarchy of the multi-level index entry that is generated. Only the final nested indexterm element contributes a page number to the generated index.

If an indexterm element also contains one or more index-see elements, only the index-see elements contribute page numbers to the generated index.
Why would the index-see element contribute a page number?
28 July 2019: I think some of the confusion here revolves around how we interpret index-see elements:
Are we talking about the "see X" information that should be rendered in the generated index at the entry generated from the indexterm element that contained the index-see element?
Are we talking about indexterm element that contains the same content as the index-see element?
If an indexterm element also contains one or more index-see-also elements, both the indexterm and index-see elements contribute page numbers to the generated index.

draft-comment.author: Kristen J Eberlein
draft-comment.p: The following RFC-2119 statement is new for DITA 2.0. Thoughts?

conbody.p: (For processors that support indexing) If multiple indexterm elements exist that contain identical content, a processor SHOULD generate only a single index entry, although all locations associated with the indexterm element contribute page references.
